faqs.question: Kunnen buitenlanders eigendom kopen in Spanje?
faqs.answer: Yes, there are no restrictions on foreign property ownership in Spain. Non-EU and EU citizens can purchase residential property with equal rights to Spanish nationals. The primary requirement is obtaining a Spanish Tax Identification Number (NIE) from the National Police. UK buyers navigate post-Brexit regulations identically to other non-EU purchasers. Spanish banking institutions readily provide mortgages to foreign buyers meeting standard credit requirements. Legal processes are transparent and well-established, with thousands of international properties transferring annually.

faqs.question: What is the rental income potential for this apartment?
faqs.answer: This 3-bedroom apartment typically commands €800/week in holiday lettings—generating approximately €41,600 annually at 50% occupancy, representing a 9.4% gross yield. Summer months (June-September) typically achieve 70-90% occupancy, while winter attracts extended-stay professionals and retirees. Long-term rentals (12-month contracts) command lower monthly rates (€1,200-1,500/month) but provide stability and reduced management intensity. Management company fees typically run 20-30% of gross rental income, leaving net yields of 6.5-7.5% after operational costs.

faqs.question: Hoeveel bedraagt de onroerende voorheffing in Spanje?
faqs.answer: De jaarlijkse onroerende voorheffing in Spain total approximately 0.4-0.75% of property valuation, paid to municipal councils—for a €441,000 property, approximately €1,764-€3,308 yearly. Capital gains taxes apply upon sale (19-45% depending on holding period), with longer ownership rewarding lower rates. Purchase taxes include 6-10% IVA (Value Added Tax) on new properties, plus 1.5% municipal transfer tax (ITP) on second-hand purchases. Spain offers non-resident tax advantages for certain situations, requiring specialist accountancy consultation.

faqs.question: Kan ik als buitenlander een hypotheek krijgen in Spanje?
faqs.answer: Yes, foreign buyers obtain Spanish mortgages through Spanish banking institutions, typically covering 60-80% of purchase price. Requirements include demonstrating income (employment contracts or business accounts), credit history assessment, and property valuation. Interest rates for foreign buyers approximately equal Spanish resident rates (currently 3-4%), with 15-30 year terms available. UK expats navigate post-Brexit requirements without disadvantage. Many international buyers maintain separate UK mortgages rather than Spanish borrowing, depending on currency management strategies.

faqs.question: Wat zijn de kosten van levensonderhoud aan de Costa Blanca?
faqs.answer: Monthly living costs for a couple in Benitachell range €1,200-1,800 (excluding housing), including groceries, utilities, transportation, and entertainment. Utility costs (electricity, water, gas) total €100-150/month depending on usage. Dining and entertainment costs align with modest European standards—casual restaurant meals €12-18, wine €5-8 bottles. faqs.question: What is the distance from Costa Blanca to the UK?

faqs.question: What is the weather like on Costa Blanca year-round?
faqs.answer: De Costa Blanca heeft een mediterraan klimaat with 300+ days annual sunshine—annual average temperature 17.5°C. Summer months (June-September) range 25-32°C, with coastal breezes moderating Benitachell's elevated position. Winter (December-February) averages 8-15°C with occasional rainfall. Spring and autumn (April-May, September-October) provide ideal conditions (18-24°C) with minimal precipitation. This climate supports year-round outdoor activity and explains strong rental demand across all seasons, particularly winter months attracting Northern European residents seeking respite from colder conditions.

faqs.question: Heb ik een visum nodig om eigendom te kopen in Spanje?
faqs.answer: Property purchase does not require visa status—foreign ownership is unrestricted regardless of residency or visa status. You may purchase property, maintain it, and collect rental income without Spanish residency permits. However, if you intend to reside in Spain more than 90 days annually, you must obtain residency permits (temporary or permanent). Post-Brexit UK citizens obtain residency through various pathways (property ownership, retirement, employment). Legal advice is recommended for individual circumstances, but property acquisition itself carries no visa requirements.
